reviews.review_title: Absolutely Worthless
reviews.content: First sign that a movie is going to suck: When there's a five minute narration at the beginning. By the time that's over it's pretty apparent what's going to happen and we haven't even seen a single shot yet. Everything about this movie was awful: Script, Plot, dialogue, characters, acting....you name it. Second sign that a movie is going to suck: Tara Reid plays an archaeologist. It wasn't even funny in any way, shape, or form. Early in the film she stumbles across a dead body and experiences what anyone would consider a traumatic time, yet when someone asks her how she's doing she's "Just shaken up" and has to catalogue some more artifacts. The dialogue was awful. There was absolutely no credible conversation. Every line was delivered to explain something, thereby killing just about any mystery that could have been generated (but then again the introduction killed that, too). Ancient Native American civilizations and mysterious paranormal stuff being tracked by a super-secret government organization? Maybe in another movie that would have been even remotely interesting, but in this movie it just falls on its face and rolls in the mud a few times while getting prodded with an electric shock rod and spit upon by school children. I guess after scoring Reid, Slater, and Dorff there was no budget left for anything else that makes a movie. It's a "B" movie all the way, and that's almost an insult to "B" movies. Avoid at all costs, even if you must gnaw your limbs off to escape. I want my money back.

reviews.content: This movie is bad beyond belief. I'm a Roger Corman fan and I can't watch this movie. One of the primary reasons for my disgust is Christian Slater. I can't believe he sold out so totally. His career will pay for this transgression. Which brings me to Uwe Boll. I've seen a million comments on how bad Uwe Boll's video game adaptations are (and I pretty much agree with them). And I've asked myself, how can Uwe make any money? Answer is simple. Hes using German tax loopholes to pay for the production, and all he has to do in return is pay taxes on any profits. By using this system, Uwe has made a pretty penny making garbage films for a living. Bad movies, brilliant profiteer.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uwe_Boll

It seldom works, and this film is no exception.Do yourself a favor and steer clear of this one. It's not even worth a rental.

reviews.review_title: Jolly Good
reviews.content: A pleasant enough romp and it's good to see Christian Slater back in a lead role.Uwe Boll clearly is a director who is very enthusiastic about his films and relishes the opportunity to film action sequences in a contemporary and engaging style.He was able to exploit his relatively low budget well with some impressive set pieces: using bullet time on a bullet shot through a block of ice and large scale gun fights. The camera was dynamic, incorporating some very nice tracking shots and aerial photography. This helped carry the momentum so that the pace was not broken.Uwe Boll has received a lot of criticism for this film, but it does not deserve to be in the "Worst 100 films of all time". Uwe is a competent director who vision of films is instantly dismissed by people drawn in by the hype of the prejudice reviews. Give this film a go and make up your own mind.It has the feel of a smaller scale Aliens or Starship Troopers and while it is not in their league, is still an enjoyable watch.

reviews.review_title: poor excuse for a movie
reviews.content: Trying to make a movie out of a video game that has the same old clichéd plot of killing everything that comes in your way is a very difficult task... looks like the screen-writers didn't come up to the challenge... they just put a story line that has almost no fluidity whatsoever and left the rest to the director who, in spite of the fact that was faced with the great opportunity (in my opinion) of making a computer game into a movie (and failed successfully), has no sense of how to offer the audience a scary and thrilling experience. The effects that show the nature of our 'heroes' (seeing, feeling that something is going to happen in the next couple of seconds), are implemented pretty much OK... but the rest of the effects i can't quite make out why were the way they were and what was the intention of the film makers in all that confusion and chaos of a movie. We can't really call acting what went on in the movie, although i was expecting something different of Chritian Slater given his previous performances... and what is with all the self-sacrifices that go on? Reall life isn't like that! oh, and one more thing.. what's with the 'city evacuated' thing at the end of the movie???? C'Mon people... put some effort into it!!! it isn't really that hard to actually make a good movie if you have a really really bad guy (by the way... the monsters were quite OK at some point... congrats to the creature developers on that one), if you have a good guy who was one of the bad guys, and an ancient civilization that new what was all about... would it have been that hard to actually research a little bit further and produce a story-line that could actually hold the viewer in his seat, instead of boring him to death with a superficial and filled with clichés one...anyway... on the whole, the movie is awful and i strongly advise you to get as far as you can from it. in case you have played the game (as i have) there will be an urge to watch it... try to suppress that urge cause it will save you 2 precious hours of your life... trust me!

There is so little that works in "Alone in the Dark" that you would think it would be easier to just list the things the movie did correct but you'll be hard-pressed to think of anything. The story is a mess, but here goes anyway: Thousands of years ago, an ancient people named the Abkani opened a doorway into another dimension filled with monsters. The people managed to seal the door but it came at a terrible price and the entire civilization vanished. Our story follows Edward Carnby (Christian Slater), a former paranormal investigator under Bureau 713 who is investigating his past and researching a series of Abkani artifacts. As more and more artifacts are discovered, it becomes clear that someone is trying to assemble them to re-create the key to the other dimension. Edward, along with Aline Cedrac (his ex-girlfriend, played by Tara Reid) and members of Bureau 713 must stop the mysterious forces at work before it's too late.

From the very beginning of the film you can tell this is going to be bad. The movie begins with a long text crawl explaining about the monsters, the Abkani and what happened thousands of years ago. This is a movie! Why can't we see this instead of hearing about it? Not only that, but the whole text crawl is narrated Christian Slater as well. Why? After wracking my brain I was able to come up with a brief outline of the plot but the story is incredibly difficult to follow. Several plot elements are very vaguely mentioned or are quickly introduced then dropped. There are side plots involving conspiracies, human-monster hybrids, past relationships between the characters and more that often lead nowhere, do not pay off or seem to contradict the actions of the characters. It doesn't help that the acting is pretty bad (the worst offender being Tara Reid) and the special effects are terrible. It's not that the monsters look all that bad, they're nothing special but decently made; it's the little things that just scream "amateur hour". For example, there's a scene where a zombified woman is running towards a character and she's gunned down with a single bullet to the head. If you're paying even the littlest amount of attention though, you'll notice that the bullet (which was added digitally) doesn't even come close to hitting its mark so she just falls over for no reason. Obvious, unexplainable bloopers like that one can be seen here or there during the film. A perfect example is a scene towards the end where a character is killed due to incompetence, the characters leave the room with the body and you can see the the actress begin to get up again before the shot is cut. Did director Uwe Boll never hear of a retake? It's like no one cared or was paying attention movie. My favorite bad moment is a seduction scene between Tara Reid and Christian Slater that is so bad, it's LEGENDARY. So here's the setup: The two of them haven't seen each other for years and they've just been attacked at the museum. They part ways and he goes back to his house, which is some kind of warehouse to rest. For unknown reasons, he leaves the door unlocked (despite having been attacked by strangers multiple times during the day) and his ex-girlfriend, who really resents him because his arrival marked her near-death at the hand of xenomorph-knockoffs, walks in. She finds him sleeping and then starts making out with him. We then have a soft-core sex scene (no nudity, the one thing that could have at least been somewhat enjoyable) and it fades to black. Why? Shut up. That's why.
Being badly acted, with shoddy special effects and an incoherent plot would have been enough to dismiss the movie as trash, but it gets even worse because "Alone in the Dark" is boring. It's never thrilling because the mysterious activities by the villains don't make any sense and are never explained. It's never exciting because the action sequences are so badly put together and the characters so bland you don't care about any of them. It's never frightening either. There isn't even a single scene where someone is alone in the dark and frightened. What does that tell you? If all of the reasons I listed weren't enough, how about a couple more? We get some locked doors that only stay locked as long as the plot demands it, a scene where the actors talks about four photos but the camera shows five, totally inappropriate music that breaks the mood and leaves you scratching your head, a ton of destruction that doesn't mean a thing, badly written, stilted dialogue throughout, and as a cherry on top, an evil, child-exploiting nun. This woman ran an orphanage and sold the children off to a mad scientist so he could experiment on them. What kind of experiments? Well our villain wanted to create half-monster, half-human hybrids... of course! When the actions of this film begin to play out, our evil nun suddenly begins feeling bad about her actions and ends up committing suicide. If you're going to be an evil nun, at least commit to it! 
Honestly, I thought this movie was going to be a lot of fun to ridicule, but it really wasn't, it's just plain awful. I can't recommend that you check this movie out for any reason, even morbid curiosity because even though there are moments where it is so bad it's laughable, it really is a dull, dreary experience to watch it. Among Uwe Boll's films, "Alone in the Dark" is one of the worst and that's saying something. (On Dvd, July 5, 2013)

Uwe Boll's "Alone in the Dark" has nothing to do with the somewhat-forgotten and underrated 1982 slasher film of the same name. It is, instead, a big-screen adaptation of the popular video game franchise; which comes to no surprise, since Boll is infamous for merging video games with cinema and creating the most repulsively bad and intellectually assaultive pieces of shit ever. This is my first Uwe Boll film, and now I see why he has been greeted by such infamy; he deserves every last bit of criticism. Here, he's taken a good premise and rendered it stupefying and nigh impossible to watch. If there's one thing that makes it endurable, it's the amount of time you'll bust a gut laughing your ass off. Believe me folks; this one is a real stinker.
 
So the film opens with an overlong text that speaks of the back-story to the film, which is read aloud, to our dismay. The back-story involves an ancient tribe called the Abskani. Apparently, they worshipped otherworldly demons, who would take over the world upon being summoned. And now, they have finally been let loose onto the modern world, and we have to watch as Boll allows these badly animated CGI beasties to roam free and do little more than just kill people.

But of course, there must be characters; and oh man, are there ever. You've got a paranormal investigator (Christian Slater), his girlfriend (Tara Reid), and some guy in police clothing (Stephen Dorff) intent on being badass. He isn't.

Is there even a need to name these individuals? Boll cares about them just about as much as I do. A few are given the kind of back-stories that should be considered necessary, even if they are lame all-the-same. Still, every single character feels out-of-place and born of a million clichés; and the actors portraying them have each seen better days, or at least the mass majority of them have. They're just plain bad here; and they aren't even the worst to be found here when it comes to performances. No, if you know your bad movies; then you'll know that the acting that REALLY, REALLY sucks comes from the supporting cast. That's one thing that Boll seems to understand, but that's about it.

I knew the movie was going to suck. I watched it because I was in the mood for something that was bad in just about every aspect of its being. So I can't say I'm disappointing when "Alone in the Dark", a film  with a perfectly interesting idea going for it, turns out to be an insanely illogical and disgustingly under-made little horror movie. Boll's idea of suspense seems to be some dimly lit places (often times, the dark cinematography seemed unintentional rather than the reverse) and slimy lizards and their worm offspring that pounce from the shadowy regions of the earth and kill you. Sure, that can be creepy and effective, but the director gets nothing right and screws up any possibility for goodness. It isn't entertaining and it isn't scary; with the exception of a gratuitous and poorly-filmed sex scene between Slater and Reid. Now THAT, my friends, is some scary shit.

I have not played the Alone in the Dark video games, and by the looks of things, neither has Boll. The fans reacted negatively to the lack of faithfulness in the film adaptation's story; which is a load of bull otherwise. Nothing could have saved it or improved it in terms of quality; the fact that it doesn't even stick to the franchise that it's built around makes it all the more down-right pathetic. And as it is, I've said all I can say about "Alone in the Dark". I hated it; every moment of it. It's silly, stupid, and if you're going to watch it at all; watch it for the surplus of unintentional laughs. And whether you like it or not, a laugh is a laugh. And unintentional, guilty joy is the only emotion you'll feel when watching a movie directed by the master of cinematic crap himself. So embrace whatever you can feel and continue to detest the rest of the ride.  Where "Alone in the Dark" stands, as cinema, is all in the title.

You know when a movie is in trouble when its foreword lasts so long that you have trouble finishing the first five lines before the next five scroll up to replace them. Clearly, Lions Gate Films hired a narrator so that audiences could keep up. Sadly, the heavily detailed preamble in "House of the Dead" director Uwe Boll's newest video game masquerading as a movie "Alone In The Dark" is so obtuse that you may want to ignore it and wait for the characters to repeat bits and pieces of it in their dialogue. Frequently, producers add prefaces because they are afraid that there is no other way to convey such an abundance of back story. Seriously, who goes to the movies to read? Most people want to watch and react rather than read. This is why many moviegoers shun films with subtitles. Anyway, this derivative, below-average, formula-driven creature feature lacks the production values and the polish that German-born helmer Boll brought to his earlier epic "House of the Dead." Believe it or not, "House of the Dead" looks like a four-star masterpiece compared to this largely humorless, overly complicated, clichÃ©d-ridden, supernatural claptrap about huge, leaping, cranium-crushing, lizards of the "Alien" variety that number into the thousands like the bugs in "Starship Troopers." No, "Alone in the Dark" is neither bad enough to qualify as campy, like those guilty-pleasure, 1950s' sci-fi monster mashes, nor does it take the creature feature flick to the next level, like the vastly underrated "Alien vs. Predator." Among a predominantly no-name cast, Christian Slater, Tara Reid, and Stephen Dorff appear to be killing time for a paycheck in this excuse for lots of second-rate blood & gore.

Fashionably unshaven, with a tattoo on one shoulder and a spaghetti-western duster draped over his buff physique, actor Christian Slater impersonates a haunted 'paranormal investigator' on the trail of a mystery about a lost Native American tribe called the Abskani. This advanced society thrived during the age of the hunters and gatherers. They opened a gateway between light and darkness and unleashed the spawn of Hell. As the Tara Reid character observes during a lull in the action: "Some doors aren't meant to be opened." Could she have been talking about the doors to all the movie theaters where this substandard, superficial adventure is being shown? These hideous demons are supposedly so ghastly that the Indians locked them up in a gold-plated Pandora's Box. Designed as they are by a special effects company called Toy Box, the monsters appear pretty phony.

As a rough and tumble hero patterned in the Indiana Jones mold, Edward Carnby (Christian Slater of "True Romance") has just discovered an ancient artifact in the Amazon basin that promises to unlock the secrets of the Abskani and these demon lizards called Xenoes. Once Carnby deplanes, an apparently invincible assailant tries to relieve our hero of that precious relic. This thuggish brute takes a couple of 9mm slugs in the chest and shrugs them off like bee-stings. Carnby finally disposes of him by body-slamming him atop a large ice-pick. Unfortunately, this drawn-out match amounts to the best thing in this anti-climatic opus. Eventually, we learn from the hopelessly overwrought script (by Elan Mastai, Michael Roesch, and Peter Scheerer) that a crazed scientist, Professor Hudgens (newcomer Mathew Walker), abducted Carnby and nineteen other kids from a Catholic orphanage and used them as guinea pigs in his nefarious experiments. Hudgens wanted to merge man with nature as the ill-fated Abskani tried. After Walker forced a slimy, squirming, centipede-like critter down all their gullets that attached itself to their spines, Carnby managed to escape and kill his parasite. The other nineteen weren't as lucky. Twenty-two years later, amid nightmares, they drop what they're doing in their everyday lives and mutate into murderous ashen-faced zombies. Meanwhile, a trigger-happy, paranormal, SWAT-team style outfit called Bureau 713, headed by Commander Burke (Kiefer Sutherland look-a-like Stephen Dorff of "Blade"), wants to wipe out these dastardly devils. Inevitably, Carnby looks for help from his girlfriend, Aline Cedrac (an abominably miscast Tara Reid of "American Pie"), a brilliant but bespectacled archaeologist who wears clothes that bare her midriff but conceal her belly button. She also has a funny way of saying 'Newfoundland.' Although neither Slater nor she conjures up any chemistry as lovers, Reid has one great scene where she punches him out for failing to let her know about his whereabouts. This scene and the first fight scene are about as good as it gets.

Although the overexposed, washed-out photography adds an edgy quality to the narrative, it makes everybody look unattractive in their pancake-thick make-up. The monsters don't appear very realistic and never pose a tangible threat. The gore is cheesy by anybody's standards. The dialogue sounds like a play-by-play commentary. The characters spend too much time telling us where the plot is propelling them or uttering inconsequential fluff to keep your attention from drifting. Most of the action occurs in a creepy mine shaft or an abandoned warehouse. At least, "House of the Dead" was fun, while "Alone in the Dark" suffers from a case of prefabricated plot. Slater and Dorff both bring more dignity to this mediocre movie than it deserves. Meanwhile, this swiftly-paced, 96-minute potboiler reaches its predictable climax without arousing the least bit of sympathy for our heroes or modern civilization.

Expect to see "Alone in the Dark'' on the Sci-Fi Channel where the commercials will provide some relief from this noisy tedium.

Let's talk for a minute about the nature of horror.  Horror, according to my little unabridged here, is "an overwhelming and painful feeling caused by something frightfully shocking, terrifying or revolting; a shuddering fear".  So now that we've established what is horrific, let's get the following out of the way; this movie is horrific, in every sense of the word.  You won't find yourself contemplating supernatural horrors, or even the depths of human depravity during the few minutes you will be able stomach this bile.
   Instead the horror will stem from absolutely horrid casting (Tara Reid as an archeologist, if wearing glasses and slapping a keyboard whilst saying inane things like "I THINK ITS ABKANI, IT MIGHT BE ABKANI, IT'S ABKANI" counts as archaeology), locations that look like the same set converted multiple times for the variety of purposes, props that are . . . laughable (all of the soldiers are wearing painball gear complete with elbow and knee pads and the ancient artifacts are cast of a crappy crappy resin mold), the extras have no idea where they're supposed to be "shooting" and so the action scenes, already bogged down by misplaced heavy metal, and .5 second camera cuts that prevent anything from being actually seen other than rifle blooms and the occasional poorly rendered CG ugly thing, and then we come to the acting.  If there were poorer acting in this film, which is about on par with a very bad SciFi original production, I might be inclined to recommend it as a good drinking game movie.  There is, however, nothing worth redeeming in this piece of utter trash.  Alone in the Dark has nothing of what made the vintage video game series so appealing, as the crew seemed to be intent on making an action movie from a horror video game.
   If the opportunity to watch this movie ever presents itself, do something more fun and productive; like smashing your head against the wall, or jumping off a roof.

rt_summary: When the investigations of supernatural detective Edward Carnby (Christian Slater) lead him to uncover a long-lost tribe called the Abskani, he finds out that they worshipped demons. These evil creatures are now attempting to resurface in the world, and Edward can stop them only with the help of Aline Cedrac (Tara Reid), an archeologist who also happens to be his old flame. With sinister forces attempting to take over Edward's mind, can he and Aline stop them before it's too late?
meta_summary: Based on the best-selling Atari videogame series, this film features Edward Carnby (Slater), a private investigator specializing in unexplainable supernatural phenomena.  (Lions Gate Films)
